Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields, making it more difficult to achieve food security. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on the variability of maize yields in major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in most of the world. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. The probability that the top four maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need to consider the taxonomic resolution of diet data when assessing the role of herbivores in ecosystems. This is especially important for understanding the role of herbivore diversity in species coexistence. Our results also suggest that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for biodiversity conservation in the United States. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). Reduced reactivity to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate might be a useful biomarker for the assessment of marijuana abuse. They also highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function.

Language is the defining feature of our species, and the brain’s processing of language is the most studied cognitive process. Despite this, we still do not understand how the human brain represents and processes language. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for predicting words in continuous text sequences also predict the brain responses to those words in human participants. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the brain may use predictive processing to solve the “language problem”: how to represent and process an infinite-dimensional language. This may be a general principle of predictive processing in the brain.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classicality and the origin of the second law of thermodynamics. However, the interplay between them is still poorly understood. In this work, we unveil the entanglement dynamics in a paradigmatic model of interacting bosons, the Lieb–Liniger model. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. Our work provides a general framework for the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems. It also opens the door to the study of the interplay between entanglement and thermodynamics in more complex systems.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that regulates the dynamics of actin filaments. It does so by binding to the barbed end of actin filaments and severing them. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that filament curvature favors severing, while tension has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. We also find that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this ADF-induced torque dramatically enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF in a variety of cellular processes, including cell motility and cytokinesis. They also provide a general framework for understanding the action of other proteins that sever filaments in a mechanical context.

Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the evidence for it in the real world is controversial. Here, we test whether emotional contagion occurs outside of in-person interaction between individuals by reducing the amount of emotional content in the News Feed of Facebook users. We find that when positive expressions were reduced, people produced fewer positive posts and more negative posts; when negative expressions were reduced, the opposite pattern occurred. These results indicate that emotions expressed by others on Facebook influence our own emotions, constituting experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for understanding the spread of emotions in society. It also has implications for the design of social media platforms.

The ribosome is a complex machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into proteins. There is a growing appreciation that mRNA sequences can also be posttranscriptionally modified. We show that the presence of one common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding in a reconstituted translation system and human cells. Our findings suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA sequences and that this can have consequences for protein synthesis. Our study provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on translation. This is important for understanding the function of mRNA modifications in cells.

This paper examines the reasons for the growth of hydropower dams in the developing world and the challenges of building sustainable hydropower. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder with no known cure. The disease is characterized by chronic inflammation, which is most often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to amyloid-β (Aβ) plaque deposits and cell death. However, this reaction is observed in transgenic animal models devoid of such pathologies. We propose that this plaque-independent inflammatory reaction originates from neurons burdened with increasing levels of soluble and oligomeric Aβ, which are known to be the most toxic amyloid species within the brain. We also demonstrate within disease-vulnerable regions of the human brain that a neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede insoluble Aβ plaque and tau tangle formation. Thus, we identify the Aβ-burdened neuron as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. We present evidence from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, that chickens were first used for economic purposes there. We show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems evolve in time in a self-regulatory way, but the system state cannot be predicted from the current state. SOC systems are characterized by the presence of a power-law distribution of time scales. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

The role of plant immune peptides in defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula. The structure is largely disordered and contains a single four-residue α-helix and one three-residue antiparallel β-sheet stabilized by two disulfide bonds. NCR044 peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. It bound to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. Time-lapse microscopy revealed that the peptide penetrated the fungal cell wall and membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. NCR044 spray-applied to tomato and tobacco plants significantly reduced gray mold disease symptoms caused by the fungal pathogen Botrytis cinerea. Our work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microbes that has been shown to influence human health. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that associate with humans, is poorly understood. Here, we present a database of human-associated viruses, which we call the Human Microbiome Project Virus Database (HuMP-Virus). We also show that the human microbiome is associated with a large number of viruses, with over 2,200 strong virus–disease associations. This database will be useful for future studies of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is because of the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties. This instrument is able to provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth in the Archean, the earliest period of Earth’s history, has been a matter of debate. The temperature inferred from isotopic data is ∼70 °C, whereas the temperature inferred from protein reconstruction is ∼80 °C. Here, we show that the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the Archean was ∼65–80 °C. This finding is consistent with both isotopic and protein reconstruction-based temperature estimates. This work demonstrates the power of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insights into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are important for ion flow and cell signaling. They are also important for ion homeostasis and blood pressure regulation. Ion channels are regulated by their pore gates, which open and close the channel pore. Ion channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channel C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide insights into the regulation of ion channels and their physiological functions. They also provide a possible mechanism for the BK channel’s normal closing and its constitutive C-inactivation. Our findings may also have implications for the BK channel’s pathophysiological roles in hypertension. (Read less)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, whether and how the brain does so is unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate the neural basis of phrase construction. We found that high-gamma power increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity was consistent with a bottom-up parser that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in many important biological processes. The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, this circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have evolved to be green. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is a complex process involving multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is associated with the progression of neurodegenerative diseases, and thus, it is important to understand the mechanisms of neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides insights into the pathophysiology of EAE and suggests a potential therapeutic strategy for neurodegenerative diseases. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. The probability of drought has increased because of a combination of factors. First, the probability of warm conditions has increased. Second, the probability of dry precipitation has increased. Third, the probability of dry precipitation occurring when conditions are warm has increased. These factors are all driven by human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad phenotypic spectrum. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) and plays a critical role in a variety of physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and show that they result in spontaneous bleeding accompanied by reduced numbers of thrombocytes in zebrafish embryos. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions, and advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of lysosomes with the cell membrane. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins, including superaggregation-prone proteins such as superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS). Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and suggests a potential therapeutic target. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. In this study, we estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y to be 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This is in agreement with the average rate of sea level rise over the same period. We also find that the rate of sea level rise is increasing. This is consistent with the findings of the IPCC AR5. Our results suggest that the rate of sea level rise will continue to increase in the future.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been steeper for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of this defining species. The results highlight the importance of the crystallographic waters in the active site and the role of the α-aminoacrylate hydroxyl leaving group in the reaction pathway. The study also demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into the chemistry of a biologically relevant intermediate. This approach has the potential to be applied to a wide range of enzymes. (Read less)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease highlights the need for effective treatments. Here, we show that the antiviral remdesivir, which is already in clinical use for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This suggests that remdesivir may be a useful treatment for MERS. The data presented here support testing of remdesivir in a MERS clinical trial. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-provisioning strategy may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbial communities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates are rising in the United States, and suspensions are associated with long-term negative outcomes. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This change in mindset is associated with a reduction in suspensions. This scalable intervention has the potential to reduce suspensions and improve students’ lives.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To infect human cells, MERS-CoV must first bind to cell receptors and then fuse with the cell membrane. The spike (S) glycoproteins are the viral receptors and fusion-activating proteins, respectively. We found that the spike proteins are cleaved sequentially during virus entry into human cells, and that the first cleavages are required for MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a major impact on these emissions. Increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering settings could have a significant impact on the environment. However, it is difficult to increase the proportion of plant-based meals offered in catering settings. We show that increasing the proportion of plant-based meals offered by doubling the proportion of plant-based meals offered from 25 to 50% increased the proportion of plant-based meals offered by 78.8% in one cafeteria. This increase in plant-based meal options was sustained over time and had no impact on overall sales. These results provide evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a panel of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. Addition of a potent MEK inhibitor that blocks MAPK signaling brings each oncogene-induced surfaceome back to a common state reflecting the strong dependence of the oncogene on the MAPK pathway to propagate signaling. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to more than 30 million confirmed cases and over 600,000 deaths worldwide. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune system, but the molecular basis for this evasion is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2, and we hypothesize that it may be important for immune evasion. Our findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2. Understanding these properties is critical for the development of effective countermeasures. Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important. Unfortunately, it is very difficult to decide which associations are important. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We show how these methods can be used to make better decisions about which associations are important.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. Although many attempts have been made to generate ECs from pluripotent stem cells and nonvascular cells, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are critical for the development of the zebrafish eye. We show that the zebrafish genome contains three genes that encode ligands for Alk and Ltk. These ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish eye. In contrast to Alk, Ltk is not required for the development of the eye. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the function of orphan RTKs in vivo and the mechanisms by which ligand-activated RTKs regulate cell fate decisions in the developing eye. Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They are divided into two groups, the human and avian influenza viruses, which are genetically distinct. The avian influenza viruses are divided into three subtypes, A/chicken/Australia/3001/97 (H5N1), A/duck/China/2895/97 (H5N2), and A/goose/China/2898/97 (H7N7). These viruses have been circulating in poultry for many years and have been involved in several human pandemics. The molecular mechanisms that govern the packaging of the viral genome are poorly understood. Here, we identified a sequence-dependent interaction between two viral RNA segments that promotes the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that it might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a major threat to human life and property, as well as a major contributor to carbon emissions. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has likely played a role in the increase in wildfire activity. However, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus that causes microcephaly and other neurological complications in newborns. Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is currently being driven by global warming. Our study highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides insights into the crosstalk between the tumor microenvironment and the microbiome and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. Chemotherapy is a major treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. We show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. Furthermore, we show that ROR1 expression is required for the ability of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel is more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating PDXs. The start of accelerated deglaciation at the end of the last glacial period is a key event in Earth’s climate history, but the cause is still debated. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions at the start of deglaciation is a plausible cause. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and a rapid advance of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. This is a unique link between volcanism and climate change, and it provides a mechanism for the start of deglaciation. The Mount Takahe eruptions are the most distant volcanic eruptions known to have caused climate change. The findings are important for understanding the causes of deglaciation and the potential impacts of volcanic eruptions on climate. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms of regeneration in the adult nervous system and for developing strategies to promote regeneration in the CNS after injury.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create genetic diversity. It is a key component of evolution, and its rate is a major determinant of the size of the genome. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions showing no detectable recombination. We also find that recombination rates peak near the start of genes and fall off sharply, exhibiting polarity. These results are similar to those observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This work provides a detailed view of the recombination landscape in a flowering plant, which is an important model for studying evolution. The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of anatomically connected brain regions, which are functionally related. Here, we used metabolic imaging to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant resting state network was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. This approach may be useful for the early diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for efficient translation and is found on all nuclear-encoded proteins. The existence of 5′ cap-like structures on mitochondrial mRNAs has been suggested, but their existence has not been proven. We show that 5′ NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. NAD-RNA is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs and mature mRNAs. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. The existence of 5′ NAD-RNA in yeast suggests that this modification is widespread in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The molecular mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not fully understood. We hypothesized that epigenetic DNA-methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in blood cells are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me alterations at certain loci in blood cells are associated with glycemia for several years during the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Future studies are needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying metabolic memory and to develop epigenetic-based strategies to promote metabolic memory in people with diabetes. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study suggests that the gut microbiota may play a role in the development of alcohol dependence. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study may contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Tomato fruit are a major source of flavor for human consumption. The production of a wide range of volatile compounds is essential for the development of this flavor, but the biosynthetic pathways for many of these compounds are unknown. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the field of plant metabolism. Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the conservation and management of biodiversity and the functioning of ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment, as well as the animal’s heading and orientation. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC while mice freely explored an open field. We found that grid cells, which encode the animal’s position, are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, which encode the animal’s heading and orientation. These results provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC and its relation to navigation. They also provide a platform for future studies of the functional organization of MEC. Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) can be transferred between plants of different species. This interplant signal is able to induce flowering in the host plant. We also show that the host plant is able to respond to the FT signal by flowering. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides insights into the evolution of flowering regulation and the evolution of parasitism. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of striatonigral fibers, which are critical for the nigrostriatal dopamine pathway. However, the striatonigral system is much more complex than this, and we show here that it contains a further subsystem, the striosome–dendron bouquets. These are specialized integrative units that are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease. The striosome–dendron bouquets are composed of striosomes, dopamine-containing dendrites, and a variety of other neurons and fibers. They are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. We found that people felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. This signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN automaticity is regulated by the interplay between Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) and the plasma membrane. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and regulates Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs. We show that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs. STIM1 regulates the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry, thereby influencing the Ca2+ release from SR and the electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the regulation of SAN automaticity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivory has not been well characterized. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type rice plants but not in RNAi lines that were silenced for allene oxide synthase (OsAOS) and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1 (OsCOI1), which are active in jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis and perception, respectively. This interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores was associated with priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in plant defense against insect herbivory. This interaction may be important for Si use in agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in murine macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism and suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome. These findings may have implications for the understanding of ether lipid metabolism in other cell types and for the treatment of phenylketonuria. This article is protected by copyright. Language is a complex system that requires the integration of multiple pieces of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to support this integration. However, the neurobiological substrate of memory in language is not well understood. Here we propose a mechanism that relies on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability to support memory. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall, which is the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. This barrier is absent in mammalian cells, which makes it possible to deliver biomolecules across the lipid bilayer of mammalian cells using DNA nanostructures. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of different DNA nanostructures for their ability to internalize into cells of mature plants, deliver siRNAs, and effectively silence a constitutively expressed gene in Nicotiana benthamiana leaves. We show that nanostructure internalization into plant cells and corresponding gene silencing efficiency depends on the nanostructure size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the nanostructure. We further confirm that the internalization efficiency of DNA nanostructures correlates with their respective gene silencing efficiencies but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. Nutrient loading from small tributaries is a major driver of coastal eutrophication, but it has been overlooked in most studies. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of nutrients to large water bodies, and that their nutrient loads are disproportionately high in dissolved inorganic forms. This is because small tributaries are more likely to be located in urban and agricultural areas, where nutrients are more readily available for algal growth. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts to reduce coastal eutrophication should focus on small tributaries.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combinations of cosmological parameters that are required to explain the observed cosmic microwave background radiation are in some sense “fine-tuned” to their current values. Our results suggest that the same might be true for the rare combinations of chemical concentrations that are required to maintain a stable, far-from-equilibrium steady state in a chemical network. This is a new perspective on the fine-tuning problem that may be relevant to the study of the origin of life.

NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) are a class of autoantibodies that cause autoimmune encephalitis. Although NMDAR-Abs are known to disrupt receptor function, the mechanisms by which they cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex, which in turn alters the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We also show that these changes are critical for the development of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also provide a framework for understanding the effects of other autoantibodies on brain function. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand the history of abrupt warming in the past. We present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was accompanied by a perturbation of the carbon cycle, which is a key component of the Earth system. The event is linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. The warming event was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. These results provide insights into the potential for rapid warming events in the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not yet delivering on its promise to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex involved in the final steps of exocytosis. Dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. However, the study of the regulation of the exocyst complex is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes in the genetically tractable organisms. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. This article is protected by copyright. Sex determination is a fundamental aspect of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study in developmental biology. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In contrast, in species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles are segregating within a single species, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that polygenic sex determination in M. mbenjii produces an interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation resulting in modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, a group of redox active molecules that are formed by the photooxidation of retinaldehyde, a metabolite of vitamin A. These molecules are implicated in age-related macular degeneration. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in retinal pigment epithelial cells, promote the photooxidation and degradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the development of strategies to reduce the formation of bisretinoids and the associated risk of age-related macular degeneration. Predators are the foundation of most food webs, and the evolution of predator specialization is a central topic in ecology. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved a modular prey-capture system, with specialized structures for each prey type. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialization is not a dead end, and that specialization can be a stepping stone to morphological diversification. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution. The fossil record for the hominin lineage between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is even sparser. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology. This finding also suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding is consistent with the hypothesis that the evolution of the human hand was shaped by the evolution of the genus Homo. (PsycINFO Database Record

The one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth, and is supplied by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and is a promising therapeutic target. However, the molecular basis for SHMT inhibition is unknown. We report the discovery of a pyrazolopyran scaffold that inhibits both human SHMT1 and SHMT2. We also report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2 that is effective in cancer cells. However, one-carbon donor formate is required for cellular SHMT2 activity, and thus the inhibitor is unexpectedly cytotoxic in a cancer cell-line screen. We show that formate is a potent glycine import inhibitor, and that formate import is defective in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a cancer cell-line screen that is uniquely sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This study provides a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapeutic. It also provides a rationale for the use of formate as a glycine import inhibitor in the treatment of DLBCL. This article is protected by copyright.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. This study shows that deforestation can have negative effects on people’s diets, and that this is a neglected area of research. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern farm machinery is a key driver of agricultural productivity, but it has also increased the risk of subsoil compaction. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a widespread risk of subsoil compaction, with potential loss of soil productivity. We also show that the total weight of modern farm vehicles is now approaching that of the largest land animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that the effects of prehistoric farm vehicles on land productivity may have been similar to those of the sauropods. Our results have important implications for the design of farm machinery and for the management of soil resources. They also suggest that the effects of prehistoric farm vehicles on land productivity may have been similar to those of the sauropods. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
